questions.text: How old are you?
Are you male or female?
What age were you diagnosed with diabetes?
Who lives with you in your home?
How many brothers, sisters, etc share the house with you (what is the total number)?
How tall are you?
Do you know this because you were measured?

questions.info: Choose whether stones / pounds or kilogrammes
questions.text: How much do you weigh?
Do you know this because you have been weighed?
Which insulin regime do you use?

options.text: I take a set amount of insulin twice a day (at breakfast and tea time) (Twice daily)
I take one injection at a similar time every day which lasts for up to 24 hours, plus I inject every time I eat with fast-acting insulin (Multiple injections / basal bolus)
I take one injection which lasts for 24 hours, plus a mixture of short acting insulin and long and short acting (mixed) insulin throughout the day (Combined)

questions.text: How long have you been on this regime?
How do you feel about your regime?

options.text: It's the best one for me
I would like to change to another regime

questions.text: How do you feel about your diabetes at the moment?
How active are you?

options.text: I do some, but I could do more

questions.text: Do you do any of the following pulse-raising sports or physical activities?
Are you active in any other ways, such as?

options.text: Riding bike to / from bus stop
Riding bike to / from train station
Playing on active games console e.g. Nintendo Wii

questions.text: Where do you do exercise or physical activity?
Who do you exercise with?
How many hours of pulse-raising exercise or physical activity did you do Last week?
Why do you do exercise or physical activity?

options.text: To make / spend time with friends
It keeps my blood sugars low
So that I can eat more
I don't need as much insulin
It helps me to lose weight
I have to do it in school
To avoid boredom / it's something to do
It's the most practical form of transport (e.g. walking back from train / bus station or school)
I do not do any exercise

questions.text: What stops or prevents you from starting to do exercise or physical activity?

options.text: I am not very good at it
I don't like / enjoy exercise or sport
If my blood glucose is low
It is difficult to manage my diabetes when I don't exercise
It is difficult to do exercise with an insulin pump
I would rather watch TV / play computer games
I don't have the opportunity to do the sports I like (e.g. swimming at school)

questions.text: Now you have answered the questions about being active, how do you rate how active you are?

options.text: I do some, but I could do more

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: Which statement best describes you?

options.text: I can manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity
I can usually manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity but sometimes I have trouble
I can manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: What makes it difficult to manage your blood glucose levels when exercising or physical activity?

options.text: Exercise makes my diabetes control worse
I am frightened of getting a hypo
I'd need to take more insulin
If my blood sugar is low then I can exercise
It is difficult with my pump

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: What usually happens to your blood glucose levels when you do exercise or physical activity?

options.text: I end up having a hypo

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: When doing exercise or physical activity, my blood glucose levels depend on?

options.text: What type of exercise I am doing
How much insulin I have taken
How much activity I have already done

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: What would you do if your blood glucose levels went higher during exercise or physical activity?

options.text: Have something to eat or drink containing carbohydrate
Check my blood glucose levels  afterwards to keep an eye on them

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: What would you do if your blood glucose levels went low during exercise or physical activity?

options.text: Wait for blood glucose levels to come back up then  carry on
Have something to eat / drink containing carbohydrate
Check my blood glucose levels afterwards to keep an eye on them

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: Which of the following would you do BEFORE exercise and / or physical activity?

options.text: Adjust the settings on my pump
Depending on my blood glucose level

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: Which of the following would you do AFTER exercise and / or taking part in physical activity?

options.text: Adjust the settings on my pump
Watch out for my blood glucose levels falling later in the day

questions.category: Managing Your Blood Glucose When Being Active
questions.text: Now you have answered the questions about managing your blood glucose when you are being active, which statement best describes you?

options.text: I can manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity
I can usually manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity but sometimes I have trouble
I can manage my blood glucose levels whilst exercising or doing physical activity

questions.text: How healthy do you think your diet is?
Do you have breakfast?
What foods do you usually eat for breakfast?
What do you drink for breakfast?
Do you have lunch?
What do you usually eat for lunch?
What snacks / dessert do you have with lunch?
What drinks do you have with lunch?
Do you eat tea?
What do you usually eat for tea?
What do you have for snack / dessert for tea?
What do you drink with your tea?
Do you usually eat a snack?
What do you usually eat for a snack?
Do you eat fruit and / or vegetables?
How many times a week do you eat treats such as sweets, chocolate, fast food, takeaways?
Which statement best describes you?

options.text: I eat three meals every day (breakfast lunch and dinner)
I often miss breakfast, but eat lunch and dinner
I often miss lunch, but eat breakfast and dinner
I often miss dinner, but eat breakfast and lunch
I just eat when I feel like it
My meals vary depending on what I am doing that day

questions.text: Who has the most say about what you eat?
Which statement best describes you?

options.text: I usually work out what I'm going to eat during the day and stick to that, so that I can take the right amount of insulin
I eat whatever I like and my blood glucose is well controlled
Sometimes I have to eat when I'm not hungry
I tend to eat the same kinds of food all the time because it makes it easier to manage my diabetes
I eat whatever I like and my blood glucose is not well controlled
I don't always eat when I'm supposed to and I have hypos

questions.text: What would you normally eat and / or drink to treat a hypo?
How often do you have an evening snack?
Which statement most applies to you?

options.text: I usually  calculate carbohydrates in the food I eat and work out my insulin accordingly
I never calculate carbohydrates in the food I eat before deciding how much insulin to take
I'm not sure what carbohydrates are

questions.text: What helps you to work out the carbohydrate content in your food?

options.text: Making a list of the amount of carbohydrate in certain foods / meals so that I know what it is for next time
Remembering how much carbohydrate is in certain foods
Someone helps me to work it out
I work it out for myself
I don't think about carbohydrates at all

questions.text: What might stop you from working out the carbohydrate content correctly in the food you eat?

options.text: I have been not taught how to do it
I know how to do it but I can't be bothered
It does say / isn't clear on the packaging
Anticipating that I will eat more than I actually do
Not having a book to help me
I always work out the carbohydrates in my food

questions.text: What's important to you when choosing what you eat?

options.text: My mum / dad / carer has cooked it for me
How it affects my blood sugar
It contains nutrients which keep me healthy

questions.text: Are you happy with your weight?

options.text: Happy and have never tried to gain or lose weight
Happy and have tried to gain or lose weight

questions.text: If you have tried to gain or lose weight, what did you do?
Would you like help / advice on how to lose or gain weight safely?
Now you have answered the questions about eating, how healthy do you think your diet is?
Do you think you test your blood glucose?
How often do you normally test your blood glucose in a day?

options.text: I don't usually test my blood at all
It varies a lot depending upon where I am or what I am doing

questions.text: What motivates you to test your blood glucose?

options.text: I always do it before and / or after I have something to eat
I want to know what my blood glucose levels are
Doctors / nurses tell me to do it
I want to get a good HbA1c result
Nothing would help me to test

questions.text: What puts you off testing your blood glucose?

options.text: Nothing, I always test when I need to
Having to stop when I'm in the middle of something
Not wanting to take my testing equipment out with me
If people remind me it makes me not want to do it
Scared that the result will be high
There's no point in testing as I do do anything with the result

questions.text: How would you describe your blood glucose test results?

options.text: They are usually high (more than 10 mmols/l)
They are usually low (less than 4 mmols/l)
They are generally within the recommended levels (4-10 mmols/l)
They always go up and down
I don't know because I don't usually test my blood

questions.text: What do you do with your blood glucose test results?

options.text: GROUP:Use them to work out how much

questions.text: Now that you have answered the questions about testing your blood glucose, do you think you test your blood glucose?
How do you feel about your blood glucose control in general?
How often do you have hypos / low blood glucose (less than 4mmols/l)?
Do you know when you are going hypo / low without testing your blood glucose?

options.text: I can't tell but others notice the change in me

questions.text: How do you feel when your blood glucose is low?

options.text: I just want to sit down
I want to go to sleep
I get a pain in my head
I start to laugh at random things and get on people's nerves
Sometimes I dream I'm having a hypo, then I wake up and I am having one

questions.text: What makes you hypo / low?

options.text: Missing a meal / not eating enough carbohydrate

questions.text: What do you do if you are hypo / low?

options.text: Have something to eat / drink that contains carbohydrate
Have a rest until my levels go back up
Alter my insulin dose (give less insulin)
Nothing, just carry on with what I was doing

questions.text: Have you been unconscious from a hypo in the last 12 months?
Did you require assistance from a medical person such as a paramedic or a doctor or a nurse or from your mum / dad / carer?
Have you ever been admitted to hospital for a hypo?
How did that make you feel?
How often do you have high blood glucose (more than 10 mmols/l)?
Do you know if your blood glucose is going high without testing your blood?

options.text: I can't tell but others notice the change in me

questions.text: How do you feel when your blood glucose is high?

options.text: I go to the toilet a lot more than usual
I have no energy and can't be bothered doing anything

questions.text: What makes your blood glucose high?

options.text: Forgetting to give insulin through my pump

questions.text: What would you do if you tested your blood and it was high?

options.text: Adjust the insulin in my pump to give more insulin
Nothing, just carry on with what I was doing

questions.info: What is ketoacidosis? Ketoacidosis occurs when there are very high levels of ketones (acid) in the blood. They appear in the urine when your body doesn't have enough insulin.
questions.text: Have you had diabetic ketoacidosis in the last 12 months (not including at diagnosis)?
Did you require assistance from a medical person such as a paramedic or a Doctor or a Nurse or from your mum / dad / carer?
Were you admitted to hospital?
How did that make you feel?

questions.info: What is HbA1c? As well as the day-to-day blood glucose testing, there is another test that monitors your diabetes management.  The HbA1c test (usually done from a fingertip blood test either at the clinic or just before your appointment) measures your diabetes control over the last two to three months. The recommended level is generally 7.5% but targets are individual and your paediatric diabetes team may suggest a different target for you. The measurement units for HbA1c have recently changed from percentage (7.5%) to mmol/mol (58mmol/l). The test and its meaning are the same, but the numbers are different. The change has been made so that HbA1c around the world is reported in the same way.
questions.text: What was your HbA1c test result when you were last in the clinic?

options.text: 9.1% or higher ( or 76 mmol/l or higher)

questions.text: What would you like your HbA1c to be?

options.text: 9.1% or higher ( or 76 mmol/l or higher)

questions.text: Now you have answered the questions about managing your blood glucose, how do you feel about your blood glucose control in general?
How do you feel about injecting or using your insulin pump?

options.text: I do mind it most of the time
I do like it some of the time
I hate it all of the time

questions.text: Who usually sets up (prepares) your insulin injections or changes the set on your pump?

options.text: Usually me, but my mum / dad / carer do some
Usually my mum / dad / carer but I do some

questions.text: What motivates you to do your injections or to give insulin through your pump?

options.text: My mum / dad / carer reminding me
My mum / dad / carer setting up the needles for me it's just part of my daily life
Knowing that it helps me to control my diabetes
I feel a lot happier when I've done my insulin
I do want to feel ill
I know that I have to do it

questions.text: Do you use an insulin pump?
Including your background insulin if applicable (basal), how many times do you inject insulin per day?
Which statement best describes you?

options.text: I never miss an insulin injection
I sometimes miss an insulin injection
I often miss my insulin injections

questions.text: What might stop you from doing an injection?

options.text: I do have any insulin left
I do want my blood glucose to go low
I do want to leave my friends
I hate having to inject with every single thing I eat
I do want to do it in school
I do want to inject in front of other people

questions.text: How many times (approximately) do you give insulin through your pump per day?
How often do you change your set?
Who inserts your canula?

options.text: Usually me, but my mum / dad / carer do sometimes
Usually mum mum / dad / carer but I do sometimes

questions.text: How often do you change your canula?
Do you use set programs for insulin doses on your pump?
What might stop you from wearing your pump?

options.text: I take it off when I'm doing sport
I forget to put it on sometimes, e.g. after sport
I take it off to shower / go in the bath
I take it off because it's uncomfortable
I do want people to see it

questions.text: Now that you have answered the questions about your insulin, how do you feel about injecting?

options.text: I do mind it most of the time
I do like it some of the time
I hate it all of the time

questions.text: Now that you have answered the questions about your insulin pump, how do you feel about using your insulin pump?

options.text: I do mind it most of the time
I do like it some of the time
I hate it all of the time

questions.text: How does diabetes affect your life?

options.text: My diabetes does stop me from doing anything
I can't always do what I want, but I manage
My diabetes stops me from doing lots of things

questions.text: What would you do if you were ill with an infection (e.g. sickness / flu) and it made your blood glucose high?

options.text: My mum / dad / carer would look after my diabetes
Test my blood glucose more than usual
I am not sure what I would do

questions.text: You are going on a day trip with your friends. Which of the following would you ALWAYS take with you?

options.text: Food to treat hypos (e.g. Lucozade / glucose tablets / banana / biscuit)
Diabetes ID card or wear ID jewellery

questions.category: Staying Over at a Friends House
questions.text: You are staying over at your friend's house. Which of the following would you do?

options.text: Make sure my friend knows about my diabetes
Make sure my friend's parents know about diabetes
Take snacks in case I needed them
Take my blood glucose meter with me
Take my insulin equipment with me

questions.info: What is a diabetic eye examination? This is where your eyes are checked using a special camera for early treatable signs of any problems that can arise because of having diabetes.
questions.text: Have you had a diabetes eye examination?
Where do you go to have your eyes examined?

questions.info: What is a diabetic foot examination? This is where your feet are checked for early treatable signs of any problems that can arise because of having diabetes.
questions.text: Have you had a diabetic foot examination?
Where do you go to have your feet examined?
Do you smoke?
How many cigarettes do you smoke in a usual day?

options.text: I smoke occasionally, not every day

questions.text: Why do you smoke?

options.text: I do want to smoke but I am addicted

questions.text: Would you like help to give up smoking?
Do you drink alcohol regularly?
What type of alcohol do you drink?
How many times do you drink alcohol in a typical week?
How much do you usually drink in one sitting?
Why do you drink alcohol?

options.text: I drink it with my family

questions.text: Do you think you drink too much alcohol?
Do you know how to manage your diabetes when drinking alcohol?
Would you like help with your alcohol drinking?
You are going to a party one Friday night with your friends and you know that they will be drinking alcohol. Which statement best describes what you would do?

options.text: I would go to the party but I would drink any alcohol
I would go to the party and have a drink but I would monitor my blood glucose levels to make sure I was ok
I would go to the party, drink the same as my friends and not worry about my diabetes
I would not go to the party

questions.text: Which statement best describes you?

options.text: I do have a problem with diabetes, it's just a part of my life
I sometimes wish I did have diabetes, but I just get on with it because I have to

questions.text: Now you have answered the questions about living with diabetes, how does diabetes affect your life?

options.text: My diabetes doesn't stop me from doing anything
I can't always do what I want, but I manage
My diabetes stops me from doing lots of things

questions.text: Which of the following people do you feel support you with managing your diabetes?
Which of the following people do you feel understand your diabetes?
Rate how you feel about your life at the moment in relation to School / College / Work?
Rate how you feel about your life at the moment in relation to Friends?
Rate how you feel about your life at the moment in relation to Family?
Rate how you feel about your life at the moment in relation to Well-being?
Rate how you feel about your life at the moment in relation to My Future?
And to finish......now you have answered all the questions, how do you feel about Your Diabetes at the moment?
